summary: This is a New York Times article from January 15, 2020, reporting on a lawsuit filed by Virgin Islands Attorney General Denise N. George against Jeffrey Epstein's estate. The lawsuit alleges Epstein trafficked and abused hundreds of girls on his private Caribbean islands as recently as 2018, used a database to track victims, and seeks forfeiture of his islands and assets. It also discusses the estate's proposed victim compensation fund.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy financier who died by suicide in 2019; accused of decades-long sex trafficking scheme on his private Caribbean islands, tracking victims via database.

persons.name: Denise N. George
persons.role: Attorney General of the Virgin Islands
persons.context: Filed the lawsuit against Epstein's estate, alleging expanded scope of trafficking in the Virgin Islands until 2018, and seeks forfeiture of Epstein's islands and assets.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: Epstein's executor who proposed turning Epstein's wealth into a victim compensation fund with confidentiality for claimants; could not be reached for comment for this article.

persons.name: Ali Watkins
persons.context: Byline author of the New York Times article reporting on the lawsuit.

persons.name: Bridgette Can
persons.role: Director of the Human Trafficking Clinic at the University of Michigan Law School
persons.context: Consulted with the Virgin Islands AG's team on the case, commenting on the legal complexities of allocating assets in human trafficking cases.

connections.description: George, as Attorney General, is suing Epstein's estate on behalf of the Virgin Islands government for alleged sex trafficking and related crimes.
Indyke is the executor of Epstein's estate, responsible for managing his assets and proposing a victim compensation fund.
George's lawsuit seeks to head off Indyke's proposal for a confidential victim compensation fund, accusing the estate of concealing criminal activities.
Can consulted with George's legal team on the case regarding human trafficking litigation complexities.

events.title: Epstein's suicide in jail
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein hanged himself at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Epstein charged by Manhattan prosecutors
events.description: Manhattan prosecutors charged Epstein with sexually exploiting dozens of women and girls in New York and Florida, with alleged actions up to 2005.

events.title: Epstein denies investigator access to Little Saint James
events.description: Epstein refused to permit a Virgin Islands Department of Justice investigator to enter Little Saint James for routine monitoring, claiming the dock was his 'front door'.

events.title: Epstein's Florida conviction
events.description: Epstein was convicted in Florida for solicitation of prostitution; his lawyers had previously said he was law-abiding since this conviction.

events.title: Epstein obtains Great Saint James
events.description: Epstein obtained his second private island, Great Saint James, through a straw purchaser.

keyFacts: The lawsuit alleges Epstein sexually abused and trafficked hundreds of young women and girls on his private Caribbean islands, with some incidents occurring as recently as 2018.
Epstein allegedly used a computerized database to track the availability and movements of women and girls, some as young as 11 and 12 years old.
The lawsuit seeks the forfeiture of Epstein's two private islands (Little Saint James and Great Saint James) and the dissolution of shell companies he established in the Virgin Islands.
Epstein's estate, valued at about $500 million, is the subject of multiple claims, including this first lawsuit by a government entity (the Virgin Islands).
The lawsuit opposes the estate executor's proposal for a confidential victim compensation fund, accusing the estate of trying to conceal criminal activities.
